data.message: Just a friendly reminder to check your email and fill out the first follow-up survey that we sent out last week. Remember, you'll receive $20 for completing it and will receive an additional $20 at the end if you complete all follow-up surveys!
Done!
I did it but didn't get the $
Did it say you were going to?  It said i was but hasnt done it yet

We apologize, sometimes it takes us a few days to process your survey and sent out the gift card. Please message us if you haven't received your gift card by next Tuesday. Thanks for your patience! :)-Shirley from TSP

#86: More and more states are raising the taxes on cigarettes. How do you feel about this as someone who smokes, and how do you feel when you think of yourself as a nonsmoker? Share your two different perspectives. #smokingaffectsall
Mmm, camel nonfilters.... Haven't had those in a while
Also raising tobacco tax doesnt do much besides make the poor poorer and make smoking even more of a financial burden than it already is. It doesn't motivate many to quit.
Interesting point 10472, thank you for sharing!

Hello TSP members! Yesterday’s post concludes our 90-day program. Please check your email this week for our first follow-up survey. You will receive a $20 gift card upon completion. We hope that our Facebook group has been enjoyable, educational, and life-changing in some way, whether it be a shift in your perspective towards smoking, or a commitment towards a healthier, smoke-free life. All of us at TSP have enjoyed reading your comments and interacting with you online, and we truly thank you for your participation.Although we will no longer be posting daily, you are welcome to remain in this secret group and access all of the content we've shared over the past 90 days. Furthermore, we're still available to answer any questions/concerns about smoking, and we're open to any feedback/suggestions you may have for our program.Again, from all of us at TSP, thank you and good luck in your future endeavors!
#90: All federal buildings, many state and local government buildings, and even some parks, beaches and playgrounds are now smoke-free. What do you think of these laws? #smokingaffectsall
Its a good thing for the non-smoking population

#89: Instead of letting the health warnings about smoking go through one ear and out the other, let them sink in: COPD, lung disease, oral cancers, cataracts, the list goes on and on. How often do you think about these diseases when you smoke? #beingconscious

#88: Research shows that one of the biggest triggers for smoking is stress. Familiarizing yourself with breathing techniques could help you relax without lighting up. Try this today when you feel stressed. Did it work? #feelinghealthy

#87: Ever wonder how much money you’ve spent on cigarettes? Use this Cost Calculator to see exactly how much you’ve spent and tell us what you would do with that money if you could get it back. #reflection
data.name: Cigarette Calculator
data.caption: www.cancer.org
data.description: Find out how many cigarettes are consumed over a given period of time. You supply the number of cigarettes or packs and the amount of time. Then press the 'Calculate' button. 'Reset' will let you try...

data.message: With the 90 days being almost over I am curious to hear about your experience: What is the most important thing you have learned from TSP? #TDII
That I can quit smoking as long as I use all my resources and stay committed
That's a positive message :) - glad to hear it 10427! How are you holding up?
Really well actually! Its been over a week now since my last cigarette and it feels great
Very cool 10427 - you deserve a pat on the back for a job well done! Have you encountered any high risk situations for smoking in the past week and how have you been dealing with them?
Before I take off for today I wanted to share two important suggestions for enhancing your long term motivation to stay quit:
Check out these health benefits
... and don't forget to reward yourself
Take care and keep up the good work! Bye
#81: When you smoke, which one of these adjectives do you feel most often? If none of them fit you, add your own but be sure to share why! #livinghealthy • Controlled• In control• Restricted
I would say in control for me
All of them.
Controlled
#84: How do you feel about a medication that changes its dose of nicotine to match the intensity of your withdrawal symptoms? Would you consider using varenicline? #beingconscious
Sounds intriguing to say the least
Never heard of it but id try it .

#85: When you think of yourself as someone who smokes, what words do you use to describe yourself? Pick one of these or add your own and tell us why that adjective fits your identity #livinghealthy • Strong-willed• Thoughtful• Inconsiderate• Determined
Im a relatively thoughtful person id say.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A this week. Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: #83: Check out this slide-show to see how smoking affects your physical appearance as well as some things you can do to combat those consequences. Click through the slides and let us know what you think! #reflection
data.name: Slideshow: Surprising Ways Affects Your Looks
data.caption: www.webmd.com
data.description: Pictures of twins show how smoking dramatically speeds up wrinkles and aging. Also covered: sagging breasts, early menopause, hair loss, cataracts, infertility, and other effects of smoking.

data.message: #82: Many states and public organizations are offering free smoking cessation programs online like buff.ly/1VAwwYX and buff.ly/1VAwuQO. How do you feel about these free resources as a smoker, and how do you feel as a potential nonsmoker? #smokingaffectsall
#80: When you don’t have a lot of time to de-stress, using this Countdown Relaxation technique can be a real life-saver. Would you use this strategy to avoid smoking? #livinghealthy

#77: Anti-tobacco messages are being shown through news articles, commercials, movie/television characters, and of course, scientific reports. Do you think not smoking is becoming the new standard in our society? #smokingaffectsall

Not at all. I believe that our society is becoming more aware of the dangers involved however and that it's taking a step towards that but it's not the new standard. Vapes are slowly becoming more of the norm I believe however I still consider that smoking
I'm not sure. With the rising legal acceptance of Marijuana smoking, I have run into less people smoking cigarettes.
Not at all.  I think smoking is becoming much less standard though

While smoking is becoming increasingly looked down upon by the general public, who view it as a nuisance and care about the health hazards of it, there will always be subcultures and social circles, and a certain percentage of the population that smokes cigarettes. It will never go away, EVER. And that's a fact and that fact is also the norm, and people should deal with it and not be a bitch about it, within reason. Like, if I was nice enough to step 30 feet away, downwind from you, please don't give me dirty looks, lol. I would understand if I was close to you, but come on man.
What is currently your biggest smoking trigger? #TDII
Driving without a doubt
Hi 10427 - driving is a big time trigger for sure! Have you ever tried strategies to curb your cravings while driving? If so what has worked for you in the past?
Well what I've been doing is just carrying a bag of sunflower seeds with me. Occupies me while I drive and helps me get over the cravings for a cigarette
Very cool 10427! How much do you smoke these days? Are you actively reducing your smoking?
Right now its been 3 days since I last smoked one. I haven't had any chances to buy a pack nor have I been around other smokers so it's been relatively easy so far

Great job 10427 - being able to not smoke for 3 days in a row is a big deal and you should be proud of yourself! Also not buying a new pack is a great strategy! Last week we talked about strategies for dealing with high-risk situations and how to decline a cigarette offer. Have you had any of these situations in the past week? How did they go?
Yes actually and it went great! They ended up expressing that they've been wanting to quit as well. But now they will no longer offer me any unless I ask them directly.

Glad to hear it worked 10427. If you are ready for even more commitment you could even tell them to not give you one even if you ask them ;) - up to you of course, but may come in handy if your willpower weakens at some point.

Before I take off for today, I briefly wanted to talk about the topic of lapse/relapse (not that I think it will happen in your case, but I am a firm believer that it is better to be prepared). Remember that even if you smoke another cigarette, it is always up to you how you continue after that. Smoking on cigarette doesn't make you a smoker again and doesn't mean you have to go back to your old smoking pattern.

Think of a slip as a mistake. Remind yourself of the hard work you’ve done towards quitting and choose not to smoke the next cigarette! But please do not interpret this as “permission” to have a slip. Remember, the surest way to quit smoking is to not smoke the 1st cigarette!
Do you think any of this will be helpful 10427? Anything else you would like to talk about before next week?
It was definitely helpful I'd say. Helps build my self confidence in staying cigarette free one day longer
#79: What have you heard about bupropion to help people stop smoking? Would you consider taking a medication if it would help you successfully quit? #beingconscious

#78: Ever notice the difference between the smokers in tobacco advertisements and the smokers you see in real life? Antonella did. Read her story and share with us anything you’ve noticed about Big Tobacco advertisements. #reflection
data.name: A Goodbye Letter to Cigarettes
data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: Nicotine addiction is like a bad relationship. You know it's hurting you, but leaving it behind is tough. This goodbye letter was written by someone who found their way free of the destructive relationship...

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #76: How do you view yourself when you smoke? Choose one of our options (or add your own) and tell us what makes you feel that way: Irresponsible, Independent, Responsible, Addicted. #knowyourself
Gross and like a baby with a pacifier because ofor the ciggarettes. But also beautiful because the act of smoking.
I'd say responsible. In a way I suppose.
#75: Meditation is a well-known relaxation technique that can be done anywhere - work, class, at home, ANYWHERE. Do you think this could help you avoid a cigarette? #livinghealthy
Yes, super healthy alternative for the moments of ciggarette withdrawal aggresion. Incense seem to help guide my meditation as well.
#74: Creating a positive association with not smoking can keep you on the straight and narrow. What small rewards could keep you motivated if you experience withdrawal while quitting? #eyesontheprize
Candy :P

#52: A private jet, glamorous jewelry, fancy nails, and of course an e-cigarette. How many ways do you see Blu trying to sell their product as something that will make you fancier, richer, and more sophisticated? Their master plan isn’t so under-the-radar! #ecig

Another ad campaign by any business.  They are trying to make it look cool to smoke by putting someone who appears to be successful I'm their ad.  Like frosted flakes and sports stars.  The only aspect that's different is that they are using a harmful product in their ad
That and they're bashing cigs. Downgrading those who don't smoke ecigs at the same time as well
Thanks for discussing!
That's funny, because Blu is an inferior product to most. They're the Pyramids and Pall Malls of vaping

#73: This over-the-counter Nicotine Replacement Therapy looks like cough drops and can help alleviate withdrawal symptoms during work or class. Would you be interested in trying this method? Why or why not? #beingconscious
I'd be down to try them. Anything that helps is a win for me

#71: Have you heard? The World Health Organization is pushing for all countries to ban indoor smoking in public places and workplaces to protect nonsmokers from second-hand smoke. Are you glad that your parents, siblings, or children may be protected from toxins with this new ban? #smokingaffectsall
Yes.
If we're talking about businesses, it should be up to the property owner and the business owner.

#72: Liz writes about how her cravings may drive her nuts in the moment, but remembers that just because she wants to go back to smoking every now and then doesn’t mean her relapse is inevitable. After reading her letter, what are your thoughts on withdrawal symptoms? #reflection
data.name: I Will Survive! - A Goodbye Letter To Smoking
data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: This letter from a forum member at About Smoking Cessation poignantly describes how nicotine addiction hurt other relationships in her life.

data.message: I know stopping smoking is not easy. How confident are you that you could quit smoking if you tried? #TDII
On a scale of 1-10 I'd say 6
Very cool 10427 - why is it a 6 and not 1 for example?
I've been slowing down a lot. I haven't bought a pack in about 4 days now and the only times I have smoked is at work when a coworker offers me one.
The fact that I still accept the cigarettes though is why I know I'm not completely ready yet. Maybe I am but it is definitely easier said than done.
I definitely agree 10427 - these are the situations that make it very hard to say no. What would it take to increase your confidence in your quitting abilities?

I'd say my confidence grows the longer it goes between the last cigarette. The more I avoid or eliminate triggers happening also increases it. This is what I've been doing to try and get to the point where I can finally say no when it's offered to me

10427, I've got to run soon, but before I take off I wanted to share some suggestions with you. One of the biggest challenges for someone thinking about quitting is declining a cigarette offer - so you are definitely not alone in this! Developing and practicing effective ways to turn down cigarette offers will reduce the chances of getting caught off guard. Here are some things you could try, if you want to (up to you entirely of course):
Here’s another tip: Respond confidently.
Thanks!

#70: Read about how smoking may have become a part of your self-image. How do you think about yourself as a smoker? Is smoking a part of who you are, or just something that you do? #knowyourself http://buff.ly/1KqFOQ7
data.name: undefined
data.caption: ezinearticles.com
data.description: A person usually learns to smoke during the changes of puberty when they are trying to establish an adult identity. Smoking gives the young person confidence which in turn allows their natural abilities to produce success in other areas. The cigarette is given the credit when in reality, it is their…

data.message: Just something i do

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A this week. Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: #68: One of the best ways to combat a nicotine craving is to keep your hands busy! How do you plan to keep your hands occupied when you get hit with a sudden urge to smoke? #beingconscious

#67: Thoughts about smoking don’t just disappear when you decide to quit. Be ready when those thoughts hit. Choose one of the following strategies that might help you stay focused on quitting. Why would it work for you? #eyesontheprize • Get up and do something active• Find a healthy way to relax or deal with the stress in your life • Keep your hands busy• Think about something else!
Option two is soooo important. I feel walks on the beach ground me into the flow of life and melt my stress away. No more need to crave.
#66: When withdrawal symptoms are at their worst, a nasal spray can be a quick and convenient way to pack a punch to those cravings. Would you ever use a nicotine nasal spray? #beingconscious

#65: Here’s a story of James, a 22-year-old man who quit smoking after starting before he was even 15. Tell us if his Quit Letter inspired you to find new reasons to quit or to reach out to someone else close to you who is trying to do the same. #reflection
data.name: A Diagnosis of Cancer Helped James Quit For Good
data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: A diagnosis of cancer at the age of 20 was the final straw that helped James decide to quit smoking for good.

data.message: #64: Some states are now banning smoking in ALL public places. How do you feel about the public effort to discourage smoking? #smokingaffectsall

I'm glad they're cutting down the risk of people getting second hand smoke and all. But at the same time it looks like the country is moving towards making it impossible to smoke if not illegal. Yes it is bad for us, extremely, however I hope those who do smoke in the future actually have places to to smoke
Maybe if I weren't a smoker I wouldn't be sympathetic to those who do. But seeing as how I'm working towards quitting, the less places I have to smoke the better
I think it's great. Smoking cigarettes should be illegal. Smoking tobacco, like real cigarettes in foreign countries isn't as harmful and thus questionable legality.
I've never known there was a difference in the cigarettes made in the US and other countries

Did you know that you can avoid almost all of the negative long-term health consequences of smoking if you quit before you are 30 years old? Does that change how you feel about smoking and quitting? #TDII
I've got to run guys - check out this study if you're interested http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1211128
Also, check out these benefits of quitting:

#63: Remember the small steps towards quitting from a few weeks ago? Let’s try another! Choose one that you haven’t tried before, and tell us how it went. #freeyourself • Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Smoke fewer cigarettes each day• Quit smoking for 24 hours

#62: Imagine you’re an executive for a large tobacco company who's been asked by a child to present at her school on Career Day. What would you say about your company’s mission? What would you tell the kids about smoking? #knowyourself
I wouldn't.

Who would do that?  Smoking is an strictly adult privilege. I cant imagine any business man or woman in the tobbaco, alcohol, or any drug business even considering discussing their work with children.  Smoking is an individual's decision to be made as an adult.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A tomorrow. Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: #61: Having a motivating and centering mantra that you can repeat to yourself when things get tough can be a HUGE help to deal with cravings. Think of your own mantra/phrase you could use when cravings hit hard, and post it here. #feelinghealthy
Its for the better

#60: Smoking can touch virtually everyone in your life. If you choose to quit smoking, how would the lives of the people closest to you change in response to your decision? What chain reaction would you set off? #smokingaffectsall
#58: Make a list here of all your pros for quitting smoking. How many can you think of? #balance
All that I can think of is that I'll save at least 15 bucks a week and my health will be better

#59: It’s time to turn over a new leaf. Collect all the things in your house that remind you of smoking (lighters, matches, ashtrays, your stashed away emergency pack) and replace them with your list of reasons to quit. Take a before-and-after pic and post it here! #eyesontheprize
Quitting smoking may not be number one on your current priorities list. What would make quitting more important to you? #TDII

#57: Statistics show that the most successful smokers use a combination of Nicotine Replacement Therapy (like the patch or gum) with some type of counseling to quit, but young adults are the least likely to use NRT’s to quit. Would you ever consider using an NRT? What about counseling to help you quit? #beingconscious
I've used nrt but it didn't do anything.  And I don't think I'd do counseling
I'm trying to quit right now with no counseling or nicotine replacement and it's pretty tough, I might try to get some patches or something soon.
I wouldn't do the counseling but I would try nrt.

Non of the NRT's have helped me. I always end up just going back. It really just comes down to mental conditioning and seldom discipline for me. If counseling can help that hen I suppose it might work.

I've been getting by alright by myself but I've also given in plenty of times as well and bummed a cigarette off a friend. As far as I can tell the commitment to staying tobacco free is all in my head

#51: Smoking can feel “automatic,” but sometimes situations arise that make us want to smoke more. Which of these are triggers for you? #beingconscious • When you’re feeling impatient • When you need a break• When you’re bored• When you’re watching TV
Driving is my biggest trigger.

Yes driving hits the switch for me.  I've been slowing down but I have to smoke while I drive.  I don't smoke at work at all anymore and I only smoke like 3 at home but on the ride to and from work I can't help it
Thanks for identifying your triggers! Knowing what they are can help you avoid tempting situations if/when you're ready to quit.
#56: Take a look at Christine’s story and share your thoughts about how smoking has forever changed her life and the way she nourishes herself. #reflection http://buff.ly/1JUxd4l
data.name: Christine - Feeding Tube
data.caption: www.youtube.com
data.description: Christine talks about what it's like to live with oral cancer, from eating through a tube to still having some hope. Watch her video and get to know her a li...

data.message: #55: Who are you a role model for? Siblings, children, nieces, nephews? How would their lives change if you decided to quit? #smokingaffectsall
They wouldn't see cigarettes anymore I guess
From me at least
#54: Bars and restaurants across the country are banning smoking. Is it legal to smoke in restaurants or bars in your state? How does it affect you? #smokingaffectsall
Doesn't affect me at all
#53: If you labeled yourself as a nonsmoker, how would your self-image change? How would you see yourself differently if you no longer smoked? #knowyourself
How would you support a friend who wants to quit smoking? #TDII

#50: One thing you can try when your cravings get bad is call someone you trust and tell them that you’re trying not to smoke. Try this instead of giving in to your cravings, and tell us if it worked for you. #feelinghealthy
#48: Gruen never thought he’d be living with cancer before he was even 18 years old.  Watch this and share your thoughts. #reflection http://buff.ly/1JO5Qry
data.name: Gruen - Cancer at 17
data.caption: www.youtube.com
data.description: Gruen was diagnosed with cancer when he was 17 years old. He tries to make the best of it, though, spending time with his daughters and ignoring people's sta...

data.message: I expressed my distaste with these types of campaigns in a previous comment.  I do believe smoking is bad for you and I do believe I should quit and so should everyone for their health.  However these sort of advertisements are too graphic and give the same sort of feeling as a threat leaves.
Thanks for sharing your thoughts, 10499!
#46: Lots of smoker's report that they smoke more often when they're stressed. What can you do differently to deal with daily stressors in your smoke-free future? #balance
Exercise is the best idea I have
Music
Both great stress-relievers! (y)

#43: Many states and organizations are releasing anti-tobacco media campaigns, like this one from the CDC. How you feel about these ads being made public on television and billboards? #smokingaffectsall
data.name: Amanda's Story - Tips From Former Smokers
data.caption: www.cdc.gov
data.description: Amanda smoked during pregnancy and her baby was born two months early. Her full story and her videos are part of CDC's Tips From Former Smokers campaign.

data.message: It definitely reminds me of my desire to quit
I support the information on the dangers of smoking and reasons to quit but the pictures and videos of cancer and disease horror stories are far too graphic.
Thanks for sharing your thoughts!

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi guys, the next Q&A session will be tomorrow. See you then!

data.message: #49: What have you heard about nicotine gum? Do you think the gum will help you? #beingconscious
I have heard that the taste leaves much room for improvement but besides that it's worked for one or two of my friends

#47: According to the CDC, 126 million nonsmokers are exposed to second-hand smoke, and the most exposure occurs in vehicles and homes. Who may have inhaled smoke in your car or home? #smokingaffectsall
Nobody in my home has and everyone who has in my car also smokes
Ditto 10427

#45: Remember that small step towards quitting you chose 2 weeks ago? Try out a different one and tell the group how it worked out for you. #freeyourself • Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Smoke fewer cigarettes each day• Quit smoking for 24 hours
I would like to say, chain smoking till you can't stand another cigarette is slightly effective but only if you have he strong decision to quit after that last pack and are prepared.
#44: What are some of your favorite qualities about yourself? How does smoking fit (or not fit) with that image of you? #balance
I'd have to say my favorite quality about myself is how easy going I am. I don't think smoking cigarettes really ties into that however
How does your smoking affect your loved ones, kids, or significant other? What do they think about your smoking? #TDII
They don't like it. Disappoints them.
#42: Has smoking changed the way you view yourself? What is your self-identity as someone who smokes? #knowyourself
No, I am a human, who midly smells of tobacco smoke.
Not at all.  I'm the same guy with a cigarette or cigar hanging out of his mouth
Weak. It's a crutch. I'm strove than his. I just choose not to be. And most people will hate this post because they don't wanna admit it.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #41: Think about when, where, and why you choose to smoke when you do. Do those situations have in anything common? Pick one of the following situations (or tell us your own) and tell us why that circumstance almost always ends with a cigarette for you. #beingconscious • When you’re drinking coffee• When you’re driving• When you’re drinking alcohol• When you’re talking on the phone• When you’re feeling down
Being a homo sapien is a real trigger for me to smoke.
Drinking, illicits, craving something else, being angry, good sex.
#40: How do you think your home environment would change if you quit smoking? #beingconscious
It wouldn't change. Never smoke at home. Only in the car or at work
It wouldn't change much.  I don't flick butts in my yard.  I don't smoke inside either
I'm sure there are tens of thousands of butts sitting in landfills because of me.
My kitty breathes better and my neighbors and friends do too also, less ashes on the porch.
#37: With all the new Tobacco Legislation, most workplaces are now smoke-free. Do you think it's better for society as a whole to have smoke-free workplaces? #smokingaffectsall
Not really..  I work in a smoke free workplace and the ways people  get away with smoking at work are a lot more dangerous than if there was a designated area

#39: Children can’t really distinguish between vapor and smoke. What they see are important adults in their life setting an example for how to take care of themselves, what they spend their money on, and their attitudes about addictive substances. Would you hide your e-cig smoking from a child? #ecig

I've never really hidden my smoking from children but then again I've never hidden it from anyone. Certainly I choose to smoke around certain people but this isn't to hide the fact that I do. So in short I guess my answer is no.

I totally disagree. Children aren't stupid. We can't be ignorant towards them. They sure can destiny's between a cigarette and a vape pen and even a joint or blunt or cigar. Should we smoke in front of them?  I don't know, but if we do, we should absolutely quit in front of them too.
#38: What have you heard about the patch, a form of Nicotine Replacement Therapy? Would you ever use it? #beingconscious
With an average success rate of 7%, its not the best thing out there. I think it is due to it only containing nicotine and none of the MAOIs in tobacco that we crave in combination with nicotine.
Once a whole tobacco alkaloid patch comes out, LET ME KNOW
I have tried it before, it didn't really work for me.
Don't really know much about them. Haven't even seen them before

And I truly think its low success rate because it is missing those other nicotine-related compounds and beta-carboline MAOIs that we all crave in combination with nicotine. Tobacco is essentially a drug trifecta, designed by evolution to be extra addictive to the humans that it co-evolved with.
People, pharmacologists, pharmacists, doctors, and researchers need to stop thinking its only nicotine that we crave. That's incredibly ignorant to assume.
Tried  it.  Didn't do it for me
Made me so sick and my arm hurt. So I took it off and just smoked real nicotine
What would you miss most if you quit smoking for good? #TDII
The social aspect of smoking
Hi 10471 - in addition to the social aspects, what else would you miss about smoking?
I guess the actual feeling of smoking. That's probably about it though.
Thanks for sharing 10471 - so other than the feeling and the social aspects there is not much else you would miss. And what would you be happy to get rid of?
The negative impacts it has on my health and the fact that it upsets my family.
Those sound like good reasons to consider quitting 10471. How do you think about quitting right now? Are you considering it at all?
I want to but every time I quit I lose all motivation to stop smoking.

That sounds difficult 10471 - I hear you. I'm about to go offline for today, but I still wanted to share some things with you that may help you when you think about quitting and your motivation. First a simple list about pros and cons
and a list on the positive health effects of quitting and how soon after quitting they kick in
Thankyou sir, I appreciate it. Talk to you soon hopefully!
Sure anytime - I'll catch you next week if you'd like.
Sounds good to me.
#36: Check out how one Tobacco company called young adult smokers 'replacement smokers' on record. What does it feel like to be part of a big, expensive marketing strategy? #reflection
Doesn't feel like anthing. I CHOSE to start smoking. No Phillip Morris representative held a gun to my head and said, 'buy a pack of smokes and keep buying them or i'll kill your whole family'
It really doesn't bother me

#30: Baby steps are required to conquer smoking once and for all. Pick one of these small steps to try and post your choice here. #freeyourself • Smoke five fewer cigarettes each day• Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Quit smoking for 24-hours
I've managed to get myself down to 2 a day. The urge to smoke is becoming weaker with each day. Here soon I think I'll be down to 1 and not too far after I'll be done completely
I've tried the baby steps approach and it always winds up failing because I find some reason to smoke another.  Cold turkey when I have the motivation is my plan
I think it would be pretty easy to delay my first cigarette by ten minutes. I'll try it out
That is great news, 10427, keep up the good work! Thanks everyone for trying these out :D
I'm down to 2 packs a week. Which still seems like a lot to me But I was smoking a pack a day. I feel that the tsp study reminds me That 'Hey you don't have smoke just because your friends are.'
#34: Let's see how many comebacks you guys can come up with for this ever-popular drawback to quitting. What will you tell yourself if this thought crosses your mind? #balance
Just increase the amount I work out
If you're afraid of weight gain spend time working out. For each time you have the urge to smoke make that 5 extra reps for whatever workouts you do that day
I haven't gained weight at all and I havent smoked in 2 weeks.
10489, that's wonderful to hear! Keep up the good work (y)
#35: When you read this statistic, who in your life do you start thinking about? Friends, family, coworkers? #smokingaffectsall
I think of my housemates and friends, whom I constantly smoke around. I always feel guilty when someone talks about secondhand smoke
Sometimes that motivates me to not smoke more than any other factor because it's completely selfish.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A this week (a little later than usual). Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: #33: Social situations can make it hard to not smoke, especially when alcohol is involved. Does alcohol affect your smoking? How would you change that if you wanted to cut down or quit? #beingconscious

#32: It’s not just your friends and family who may want you to quit! The Surgeon General’s office, the Center for Disease Control (CDC), and other national organizations are urging people to quit smoking. How does it feel to see our society moving towards a tobacco-free mindset #smokingaffectsall
It feels like step towards a healthier nation.
Feels amazing. I'm happy CVS stopped selling cigarettes, makes a statement.  Even when I'm smoking I still feel that way.
#31: Turn it up a notch. Tell someone special about the small step you tried yesterday. How did it go? #freeyourself
I told them I haven't smoked in two weeks. They said they were proud and then started talking about how they wish they could quit.
I smoked a pack and a half yesterday and only three so far today.
Today, I wanted to ask you about smoking and alcohol use. Is there a connection between the two in your personal experience? #TDII
Oh definitely. I don't have to drink and smoke but when I do I can easily burn through more than one pack
Yes, it is very hard for me not to smoke when I am drinking. When I drink I smoke cigarettes one after another.

It's easy for me to not smoke and drink when no one else around me isn't and I don't have one. But as soon as I smell burning tobacco with alcohol in my system is when the urge to smoke is at it's worst
Thanks for sharing guys! I agree - the combination of alcohol and smoking makes it really hard to abstain for many people. What do you think are the reasons the two go together so well 10427 10471?
I'm honestly not sure, a chemical reaction possibly?

For me it's the distinct feeling of inhaling the cigarette. Getting the nicotine rush. When I'm drunk that feeling is multiplied almost. It's more enjoyable than when I'm sober. Why that is exactly I'm not sure

Great suggestions guys - and you are both right, there is a chemical interaction between the two that makes the use more appealing. The social situations most likely has to do with it as well with other smokers around etc. So if you ever wanted to smoke less in these kinds of situations what could you do? What are your options 10471 10427?
Not buy a pack before drinking and try to stay away from other who are drinking as well. Chewing gum or sunflower seeds work really well for me whenever I don't want to smoke in any situation.
Well I always kind of assumed I would have to stay away from drinking and other people who smoke for a little while once I quit.

Both of these are good options. Given that alcohol is a big risk factor for smoking it may make sense to not go out to drink, at least initially after you have quit 10471. In the long run, it is also a good idea to come up with alternatives, just like you suggested 10427. Other ideas for alternatives include Keep your hands busy: Use a stress ball, play a game on your phone, play with a Rubik’s cube, start a fun arts and crafts project. Keep your mouth busy: Use gum, hard candy, mints, chew on toothpicks, prepare healthy snacks like veggie sticks, drink plenty of water Any of these sound useful to you guys?
I tried chewing sunflower seeds to keep my mouth busy, but it didn't really help much last time I quit. I will have to try keeping my hands busy as well next time.

Very useful. I always carry sunflower seeds on me as I'm attempting to quit now by weening myself off them. The salt seems to help but I've never tried to use that while drinking as well since the opportunity has yet to come around

Great - one more thing that may be useful is to ask your fellow smokers not to smoke around you and not to offer cigarettes. Most smokers are usually quite happy to help others quit. At the very least worth a try :) So how do you guys think about quitting at the moment? Are you considering to give it a try at all 10471 10427?
I want to quit sooner than later, I might stop smoking soon

I definitely am. Currently I'm down to 2 maybe 3 a day as I'm working so much and my coworkers who smoke help remind me to limit my intake. Same with my friends. It's getting easier each day to resist the urge but some days do prove more taxing than others
I think I'm close to being ready and it's a good feeling. Better than I anticipated

That's great to hear guys - keep up the good work! You can also help and support each other! What are your high risk situations and what can you do to not smoke when you have an urge in these situations?

Driving, being around smokers, being drunk, and when I'm stressed. In each situation there's definitely other things I could do to occupy myself. I just have to remind myself each time to stick to it and in the long run it's definitely worth it.
Pretty much exactly what 10427 said ha
Yes 10427 - to give you some extra incentive, check out this chart:
10427 - it sounds like the sunflower seeds are working well for you! 10471 which of the strategies to distract yourself do you think may be useful?
For me there certainly is. When I drink I tend to chainsmoke heavily.
Hi 10418 - so if you wanted to smoke less in these situations how would you go about it? What could work for you?

Great discussion today guys - I'm about to take off for today, but wanted to give you some more information on what I consider the most important steps towards quitting for good. There are several aspects to it: 1. I would recommend to pick a quit day and following through with it. 2. Get support from family/friends/colleagues. 3. Learn new skills and alternative behaviors for your high risk situations. 4. Depending on how much you smoke, I would definitely recommend that you consider trying some form of nicotine replacement therapy – we know that using these can dramatically decrease your cravings and withdrawal and increase your chances to quit for good. 5. Be prepared for relapse or difficult situations (e.g., alcohol, being around other smokers, stress, etc.). I know this sounds like a lot, but we will cover each of these aspects more in depth over the next weeks. How does this sound? Anything there you think may be useful?
I think simply not supplying myself with cigarettes is the only option.  I lack enough willpower when under the influence to practice self control.

#26: Studies of former smokers show that it is extremely helpful to know where, when, and why you are most likely to smoke. That way, when you’re quitting your habit, you can plan ahead for those situations and won’t be caught off guard. Which situation are you most likely to smoke in? #beingconscious • When you first wake up in the morning• When you’re stressed• When you’re socializing with friends• When you’re tired• When you’re in a bad mood
The biggest trigger for me is when I'm drinking. It's so hard for me not to smoke when I've had a few drinks

Normally I can make a pack last a week but with alcohol in me I can burn through 2 maybe 3 packs easily. I usually smoke while driving as well. Other than that being with my friends definitely increases my chances of it
^ Yeah, driving is a big one for me as well.
Anger is probably my biggest trigger because it calms me down before I actually lose my cool.
Thanks for identifying your triggers! Knowing them will help you avoid tempting situations if/when you're ready to quit.
Driving
Drinking, walking, when I first wake up.
#29: Hoping to be prepared for withdrawal symptoms? Learn about what to expect at the link below. How are you planning to deal with these symptoms when you decide to quit? #balance
data.name: Do I Have Nicotine Withdrawal?
data.caption: smokefree.gov
data.description: When you stop smoking, you may experience symptoms of cigarette withdrawal. Discover how to identify and prepare for these symptoms.

data.message: #28: In a survey of 800 New Yorkers:• 81% agreed that most people would not hire a smoker to take care of their children• 72% agreed that most non-smokers would be reluctant to date a smoker• 39% agreed that most people think less of a person who smokes• 21% agreed that most people think smoking is a sign of personal failure What do YOU really think of smokers when you see them on the street? #knowyourself
Considering that I smoke I really don't think twice when I see somebody smoking.
It's disgusting and they imitate babies with a pacify throwing a tantrum when hey don't have one. I think this even when I'm on a smoking binge.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #27: If you want to get info about how to quit smoking, where do you go? How do you know the source is true? #beingconscious
I have asked my doctor about it in the past, he seems pretty knowledgeable about smoking cessation.

#24: Big Tobacco is advertising e-cigarettes as a safer and better way to smoke, but studies have shown that they still contain toxins. Why do you think so many people are ready to adopt them even before proper research has been conducted? #ecig
Because you can smoke more! It feeds the addiction. Smoke inside outside. Never goes out. Doesn't cost as much. Etc.
Great answer, agreed!

#22: It’s no shock that tobacco companies spend loads of time and money thinking of how to appeal to a younger crowd with fresher lungs. Check out this document, straight from a major tobacco company. How does it feel to be targeted by a huge, expensive marketing campaign? #beingconscious
Honestly is doesn't come as much of a surprise, we are targeted by different forms of marketing every day. Alcohol companies do the same thing. It's terrible, but that's just good business.
It's just a company doing what it has to do to survive. I'd be more surprised if they didn't.

Every company tried to appeal to as many different demographics as possible.  While tobacco companies have a bad name because they serve a potentially deadly product, they are a business looking to stay afloat and make money.  It's a business and as bad as it may be its doing a good job.
Good points, thanks for discussing!

#21: Flavored cigarettes have been outlawed for years now, yet e-cig companies are using old tricks to gain new customers while they still can. Would you have started smoking at an earlier age if the product you used was flavored like your favorite candy? #ecig
I started smoking at 14. Mostly because I was told not to. Had there been flavors I would have started smokingvatvthe same time. But I would have smoked way more than what I first did.

No I was warned about how bad cigarettes were from a young age and stayed away from them.  I tried marijuana first because it was less opposed by my family and moreso hidden.  Then when I tried it and found it to be harmless I tried other things starting with cigarettes.  I've been smoking full flavor pall malls since I was 16-17.  Even when the flavored e cigs came out I stuck to the ones that resembled cigarettes or cigars flavor wise.
I actually like the taste of regular cigarettes better than e cig flavors, but when I first started smoking I probably would've smoked more often.

I feel I would have smoked at the same age I had. Certainly it would have been more appealing though. These days however I find flavored smoke, or ecig smoke period, to only be appealing once in a while
Thank you for sharing!

#25: Take a few deep breaths to center yourself the next time your cravings are getting to you. Try it out today and tell us how it went. Were you able to put off lighting up for a little while? #feelinghealthy

#23: Breathing and relaxation techniques can be really helpful when you quit and enrich your daily life. Here’s a link describing a few different techniques -- try one out and tell us how it went. Which one works best for you? #feelinghealthy
data.name: How A Few Deep Breaths Can Stop Smoking Urges
data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: Deep breathing is a useful tool for immediately shifting your mind and body's reaction to smoking urges during nicotine withdrawal and beyond.

data.message: Do you think you will EVER be ready to quit smoking? Why? Why not? #TDII

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A this week. Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: #17: All change has pros and cons. What are some of the cons of quitting smoking? Why might it be hard for you to quit? #beingconscious
I think it will be hard to hang out with a lot of my friends who smoke after I quit. A majority of my friends smoke so it might be difficult to get away from other people smoking.
Thanks for sharing!
#14: On a scale of 1-10 (with 10 being most important), how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #beingconscious
I would say 8 or 9. I really don't want to continue smoking
I'd say 10 concerning quitting habitual smoking, but I wouldn't mind a social smoke once in awhile.
10, I'd love to quit for good
10 my family's health is at steak most importantly my daughters
Definitely a 10.
Right now a 7 but as I get older, an 11.
Now probably a 5.  I really enjoy smoking.  I'd only like to quit for the financial benefits really..  I know its bad for me but I like the feeling of it and the distraction it provides
I'd like to quit in the near future absolutely,  but that's why I'm here is to make myself want to do it.
I would say at the moment, a 5. I would LOVE to quit but at the same time I still enjoy smoking unfortunatley
Thanks for sharing your numbers and where you're at in terms of quitting :)

#20: Part of the new Tobacco Legislation is that physicians and clinicians must encourage and help their smoking patients quit. Do you think help from a health professional would motivate you to quit? #smokingaffectsall
My doctor advises me to quit all the time, I really don't think that has any impact on how much I want to quit
I don't think a health professional would necessarily motivate me to quit but I do know they could have the most resources at their disposal to help me if I choose to do so
#19: Who’s that one friend you can count on to listen to you when you need it? Who will you be able to trust as your supporter when you are ready to quit smoking? #support
I don't really have many friends who live near me that don't smoke honestly, most people here smoke.

My girlfriend will be my biggest supporter as will all of my friends. Even the ones who do smoke. We all want to quit but none of us are exactly ready. Once one of decides to though we'll all commit to making sure whoever wants to can and will quit. We're all in it together so why not make it as easy as possible

#18: Now that you’ve made your list of cons for quitting smoking, let’s consider your top reason not to quit. Post your #1 Con for quitting here and tell us why it’s your biggest concern. You can finish this sentence: 'I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that ________.' #beingconscious
I want to quit smoking but I like smoking therefore it's a struggle sometimes.
I want to quit smoking but I feel like smoking has become a huge part of my life so it will be hard

#16: Quitting can help preserve our planet! Without cigarette smoke, the chances of household fires decrease and less secondhand smoke is released into the air we breathe. Can you think of any other environmental improvements that might result from less smoke? #beingconscious
Less cigarette buts polluting the earth is a big one
Yes! Less littering! :D
Littering is probably the biggest impact they have.  The pollution is really not as much as its made out to be but a cigarette butt takes about 100 years to fully decompose..
Well less cigarettes being smoked means less packs being made so less waste essentially is being produced along with the littering.

#15: What strategy do you plan to use when you do decide to quit smoking? Will you use any Nicotine Replacement Therapies (like patch or gum)? Medication? Cold turkey? Counseling? Share your plan of action and see if any other group members are on the same page! #beingconscious
I think I'm gonna keep vaping when I do, and use gum or patches.
Just emotional commitment, Wasabi peas and candy. The Wasabi is great cause I get really really hot ones so I cannot possibly think about a cigarette because it's just too freaking hot.
For all the times I've tried I simply went cold turkey. Having no money to spare also helps. This time around I'm cutting down
Cutting down slowly*

I also plan to cut down slowly. I smoke a pack and then some everyday, so I'm going to start at 16 a day and cut down by 2 every week. When I make the jump and completely stop smoking I plan too use nicotine gum.
I've tried them all.  Cold turkey is difficult but the way to go,  cutting down never worked for me,  I've tried several times
Have you ever noticed a connection between smoking and your mood? Is there an emotional state that gets you to light up more frequently? #TDII
Feeling stressed or depressed always led me to smoke more.
Hi 10476 - yes, these are definitely common emotional triggers. Have you ever tried alternative strategies to cope with stress or depression? How did it go?
I don't have the best coping skills. I tend to eat more when I'm stressed or whatever I'm feeling. The only reason I haven't changed that habit is because I'm still very healthy.
I understand 10476 - how motivated are you to quit smoking on a scale from 1 (least) to 10 (most)?
That's pretty high. Why is it a 8 and not a 1 for example. What are your reasons?
I'm only 23 and I've been smoking for 10 years. It's expensive, costly to my health, and sets a bad example for my son as he gets older.
Yeah, I've noticed that when I am stressed out and when I am driving or doing other monotonous things I tend to smoke more
10476 - these are all important reasons. What would it take to move you up to a 10? And what would it take for you to try to quit?
Probably finding out I had a smoking related disease. But I am currently trying to quit now. I've had less than half a pack all week.
Thanks for sharing 10471 - what can you do to cope with boredom or stress other than smoking?
Well, my dad recommended that I eat sunflower seeds when I'm bored and feeling like I want a cigarette.
It's great that you have decided you want to try 10476! What are the hardest situations for you to not smoke? How are you coping with your urges?
10471 - that sounds potentially very useful. Have you tried it at all? How did it go?

I'd say stressful situations are the the hardest. So far I haven't had many urges to smoke. So far the cigarettes I've smoked this week were offered as a social smoke rather than 'needing to have one'
That sounds really good 10476! How can you approach these social situations without smoking moving forward? What are your options?
I like smoking..  I'd like to make that stop
The only difference mood makes in my smoking is I smoke more when I'm stressed rushed or upset.  I smoke a lot regularly though
Sorry I've got to run guys - check out this list of pleasant activities if you'd like. Maybe you'll find some of it useful. See you next week! Bye.
Darn..

#10: Remember Drawback #1 ('I don't want to have withdrawal symptoms') from yesterday’s post? Which one of our following comebacks works for you? #balance • Some withdrawal symptoms are actually signs that my body is healing• I may be coughing more because the cilia (hair-like structures that line my lungs and clean the air I breathe) that were paralyzed by the cigarette smoke are starting to work again, which makes me temporarily cough more• I may have tingling in my arms and legs because my circulation is improving

10418 Withdrawal symptoms are not really something I consider when thinking about quitting because I know it's my body healing the damage I've done to it. For me I feel my main problem is actually pulling the trigger on this and trying to quitLikeMoreJust now
Only thing I've really dealt with is the coughing.  Which goes away after a while and its kind of nice to know all that nasty stuff is getting out of your lungs.   Not pleasant but satisfying?
The coughing is my least favorite part as well, but at least it doesn't last forever.
I've never really experienced any withdrawal symptoms before. Guess everyone is different

#12: Did you know that the number of non-smokers affected by second hand smoke is more than double the number of actual smokers in the U.S.? Who is affected by your second hand smoke? #smokingaffectsall
The people who are affected by my smoking are just random people on the street
The people who are affected by mine smoke as well so it's not really a problem. Tends to be the only time I smoke around other people.

I am a very respectful smoker.  I do not smoke around children,  and I am courteous in asking non smokers if they mind my smoking.  I am completely aware that not everyone smokes and not everyone wants to be exposed to it
Everyone is affected by my second hand smoke because it goes into to ozon and effects the overall ecosystem.
Wow. Children being exposed is really messed up. But I also wonder about pets and global warming.
My kitty! He's mostly an outdoor cat, but we do smoke in our house so he is exposed to it when he comes in for food/sleep/love

#9: Research shows that emphasizing the benefits of quitting over the drawbacks helps smokers quit their habit for good. Try your hand at making a negative a positive. What’s your comeback for this drawback? #balance
It only lasts a little while, and then you feel great for the rest of your life knowing you quit
It's not that bad.
Would you rather have withdrawal symptoms or cancer symptoms. One's easier to overcome than the other. Your choice.
You'll have to go through it someday. They won't let you smoke when you're in the hospital dying of cancer.
It's all in your head really.  Only symptoms I ever had was wanting a cigarette.  Which that can make you kranky I guess but its not that bad
Driving is very stressful without a cigarette and makes me very mad
I find driving much more stressful without a cigarette as well 10488

Withdrawal symptoms are not really something I consider when thinking about quitting because I know it's my body healing the damage I've done to it. For me I feel my main problem is actually pulling the trigger on this and trying to quit
Great comebacks!
I don't know what I'd do without my morning cigarette. Except smell better when I go into work. Then maybe customers will feel more inclined to buy something from me!

#11: Everyone wants to know whether electronic cigarettes can help smokers quit. Unfortunately, studies are showing that they are not any more effective than a placebo. So health professionals still recommend using well-studied strategies like counseling or Nicotine Replacement Therapies (patch, gum) when you’re ready to quit. What are your thoughts on e-cigs? Have/would you ever try one? #ecig
My strategy right now is using a vape to quit smoking. It was helping a lot at first but now I find myself picking up a cigarette more often than a vape
I have tried it and its not for me.  Vaping is like a tease.  It's like your smoking but you can tell it's fake and it makes you want the real thing.  At least in my case

I bought an ecig about 6 months ago, for two weeks or so it did help me cut down on smokingand then I got bored of it and only used it for amusement after that. Not a very effective aide but I have tried nicotine gum and plan to use that to quit.
I have used the gum before but it doesn't satisfy the urge to smoke just the nicotine cravings.
Thanks for sharing your experience.

The placebo effect works great for some people, so if others are able to substitute e cigs for cigarettes, then awesome for them. For me, smoking seems to be something I do out of boredom or stress, and I pick up a cigarette purely out of habit. If I learned better ways of coping and keep my hands occupied, quitting would become exponentially easier. The patches irritate my skin and I don't like chewing gum, but I have tried Chantix before with great results. Unfortunately, I have terrible anxiety and Chantix completely intensified it, so I had to stop taking it. But otherwise, it's the most effective thing I've found
#13: Do you know anyone who has died from a tobacco-related disease? How did their death affect your own smoking? Post and share your experiences. #reflection
I don't know anyone personally who has
I have known people who's parents have passed from lung cancer.  That was very sad to watch them go through.
Haven't known anyone personally to die from lung cancer, I have seen friends lose loved ones though and that was hard
I also have never lost anyone but my grandfather had lung cancer and managed to overcome it. He still smokes but not often.

My boyfriend lost his grandma to lung cancer a couple years ago. The hardest part of it in my opinion was the fact that even though she was on her deathbed, she was so addicted that she would wheel herself outside in the 110 degree weather just to have a cigarette.

#4: For any of you who aren’t sure what an e-cig is, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulation. If you were a minor, do you think an e-cig would be more appealing and “safer” to try than a traditional cigarette? #beingconscious http://buff.ly/1emrhYm
data.name: Electronic Cigarettes (e-Cigarettes)
data.caption: www.fda.gov
data.description: Electronic cigarettes, also known as e-cigarettes, are battery-operated products designed to deliver nicotine, flavor and other chemicals. They turn chemicals, including highly addictive nicotine, into...

data.message: I personally never smoked ecigs when I was younger, but I have definitely seen a lot of teens smoking them. Personally I am trying to use a vape to quit smoking cigarettes and just hoping that the impact on my health isn't as bad as it would be if I kept smoking cigarettes.

I think vapes are a good alternative for anyone. Kids are going to smoke cigarettes regardless of any law put in place. But if we can provide them with something safer, then by all means, that's what we should be doing. If ecigs were widely popular when I was a kid, I would have much rather taken that route and maybe I wouldn't be a cigarette smoker today. Vapes seem to be less habit forming, but more 'trendy'

Offering an alternative for tobacco smokers that seems safer maybe? Personally I think neither is safe but you probably should move to vaping to quit smoking, my sister uses hers quite a bit and its cut her smoking habits down. The away the vapes are made though I'm not sure if its just the increased wattage of the battery or what but I've seen too many of them blow up or cause terrible burns so I'd never use one
Thank you for sharing!
Anyone who thinks propylene glycol, nicotine, and vegetable glycerine is just as damaging as the 4000-6000 chemicals  found in tobacco smoke is just ignorant.vaping IS safer. by logic alone.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: #5: Many e-cig companies are actually owned by BIG TOBACCO companies. What do you think their motives are? To have you remain a loyal customer? To help you quit smoking? Other ideas? #ecig

I think ecigs can be used to help people quit smoking, but I also think that they can and are being used to pull in people who don't like smoking regular cigarettes, whether it's because of the taste or the feeling of the smoke.
Money money money. Not to help.
This is actually bullshit, though. Most vapes that people use are NOT made by big tobacco. The ones that big tobacco companies make are inferior to the ones made by smaller companies anyways.

Also, did you know that nicotine alone is not addictive? That's right folks, you heard it here first. Nicotine is only extremely addictive when an MAOI (like those found in tobacco) is coadministered. That's why many smokers who switch to vamping feel 'something is missing'. Look it up. So no, they're not trying to lure anyone into addiction, it is truthfully a safer way to get your nicotine.

It's big tobacco. Everything they do is for profit.  They've killed millions of people with their product. They saw opportunity in e cigs with most of America trying to live a healthier lifestyle. That's the ONLY reason they've made a healthier product. Not to mention it makes an even easier target to people who otherwise wouldn't have ever smoked
Thanks for sharing your views.

#8: Here are some things to help you maintain your awesome physique when you stop smoking. Which one seems the most helpful? #balance • Make sure you have a well-balanced diet• Chew sugarless gum when you want something sweet• Eat slowly• Plan healthy, low-fat and low-calorie snacks into your day• Watch portion sizes• Read food labels

That's really difficult for me.  I work 84 hours every week so being able to have any sort of controlled diet is a challenge. Don't have enough time for a balanced breakfast or lunch,  then by the time dinner rolls around I just simply do not feel like cooking most days
Fuits!
Working in a convenience store makes watching your eating habits very hard but I do love fruit quite a bit
Understandable about the long work weeks also makes you want to smoke more especially to and from destinations such as work or home
Have you ever tried to quit or reduce your smoking? Which strategy did you choose and how did it go? #TDII
I've tried smoking only one a day before but that was a challenge sometimes
Hi 10427 - definitely sounds like a challenge. How did you make it work though?
I've got to run - see you next week!

#7: Weight gain is one of the top concerns for almost every smoker. We’ve made a list of some tips that can help keep your weight on track while you quit. Pick the one sounds good to you. How could you implement it into your life? #balance• Go for a walk, swim, bike ride or any exercise you enjoy• Find small ways to be more active, like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or parking a little farther away• Find alternatives to snacking, like calling a friend• Drink some extra water
Water is a great way to not be hungry as well before you eat drink a fall glass of water. Makes you feel more full. I suppose drinking water would work the same way
Well I already work out multiple times a day and drink lots of water,  my plan when I do quit is to just turn the excess fat into muscle
I just eat a whole lot of candy and coffee to get me hough the first few weeks and then start hitting the gym as an alternative and loose the 5 pounds I gained.

I've noticed that a lot of the time I drink coconut water but be weary in which ones you drink check sugar content if you are already active (I'm on my feet for my entire shift) it shouldn't be that big of a deal. The coconut water seems to be more hydrating and I have lost a couple pounds in the past month but the smoking always helps put it back on
I've never noticed any weight gain in the few times I've quit
Why is it that weight gain happens? I've never even heard of that before. I've also never gained weight the times I've tried quiting
Makes your metabolism slow down maybe?

I need to exercise more and eat better anyways, tried jumping on the trampoline with the niece and nephew and was exhausted after 10 minutes. I thought I was healthy because I'm pretty skinny, but I'm super out of shape. So hopefully weight gain won't be an issue when I can finally quit smoking

I don't have a car, so I walk almost everywhere as it is. I wasn't actually aware that quitting may cause weight gain though. I also try to stay as hydrated as possible. So hopefully weight gain will not be to much of an issue when the time finally comes
#6: What would be the best-case scenario if you quit smoking? #balance
I would like to quit smoking and never start again, and I would also like to decrease my run time significantly.
Id be socially comfortable with my kebistetics and mental awareness without a cigarette crutch.

My struggle is that every one of my friends smoke so when I'm alone I don't have the craving. I don't smoke. But when I'm with friends who constantly chain smoke and I smell it, I love the smell of cigarettes I smoke. But I would breathe so much better when I quit.

Best case scenario is that I quit and I'm done with them. The risk of cancer decreases, I save money, nothing but good would come from me quitting. Which is why I decided to start today. Day 1 is almost over and it wasn't that bad so far
My best case scenario is my goal of quitting in the future. For both health and economics reasons.
My health has only been minimally affected as far as I'm aware, but my wallet would thank me.
I would definitely have more money to buy other things that are needed like planing my little girls first birthday and helping my husband see the importance of quitting for her and our health reasons
Best case senario, better health, no taking time away from work or hanging out to go smoke, more money, less debt,  freedom
More money,  better health

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 11.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you then!

data.message: Hello TSP members! While we wait for more people to join us, we want you to know that this secret group is a great place to share your thoughts and engage in conversation. Please feel free to like or respond to each others' comments and share any relevant content of your own.To begin, let's take a moment to get to know each other a little better. Feel free to share with us:• Where you come from• Anything about your smoking (how much, how often, when you first started, etc.)• What you hope to gain from participating in the Tobacco Study ProjectThank you! We hope you're as excited as we are!

Well, let's see. I'm from Illinois originally. I joined the Army about a year and a half ago and I am currently stationed in beautiful Monterey. I quit smoking for about 8 months when I first joined, but that was because I wasn't allowed to smoke in basic training or during my job training. Now I smoke about a pack a day, and I am trying to cut back by vaping. I joined this group because I am trying to quit eventually, so why not get some advice and make a few dollars in the process!

I'm from a small town in Texas called Cleveland. I live with my husband and my nine month old daughter, since I have had her I've wanted my husband and I to quit smoking for good. My smoking habits decreased for about a month and eventually I'd stopped for about two days. Soon after I started back, with that said I'd really like a little guidance in quitting for good and remaining that way the money part is just sweetening the deal.

The reason I'm here is because I am 23 years old, and already, I'm noticing major negative impacts on my health from smoking. My first cigarette was at the tender age of 13. My gums look awful, I smell awful, my bank account is dwindling away to big tobacco companies. The ONLY reason I smoke is simply out of mindless habit. I don't even enjoy it. Ugh

I'm 19. And am currently living in Michigan. I started smoking when I was 14yrs old I go through stages where I smoke a pack a day. But I also go through stages where I don't smoke at all. I quit smoking all the time. My friends all smoke and I love smoking. But I know Its bad and that I have to quit before I get much older.
I'm 10483, from Minnesota. I've been smoking since I was 14, so about 7 years. I would like to quit but have only gotten down to a few cigarettes a day before starting up again.
Thank you so much for sharing about yourself. Nice to know a little more about you! :D

I'm 10427 from South Haven, MI. I'm currently 19 and started smoking consistently around 16 years old. I smoke, on average, a pack every other day or so only because I've begun to ween myself off. I've attempted quitting 4 times in the past year and it hasn't quite worked yet but I'm getting there! What I hope to gain from this is some motivation from like-minded individuals. Looking forward to getting to know you all better and helping each other in whatever ways we can.
#2: Educate yourself on the smoking rates and laws in your state. Search up “smoking information” or “smoking bans” in your state. Did any of the information surprise you? #smokingaffectsall

Interesting, after looking up the smoking regulations in California it was all pretty straightforward but when I looked into Monterey smoking regulations I found out that it is illegal to smoke on some of the piers here. That might have just saved me from a pricey ticket.
I live in Texas and have come acquainted with the laws. Prior to Texas, I lived in Michigan and their laws were more strict depending on which county.
Thanks for knowing your laws!
Apparently out of the 60 most populated cities, okc is one of the 15 cities that have NOT enacted a statewide ban against smoking in bars or restaurants.
As far as I can tell Michigan's only smoking ban is in restaurants, bars, etc. If anyone knows of any other bans currently in place please feel free to let me know.
#3: How would you support someone who tells you they want to quit smoking? #motivation
Figure out y they smoke and help them find an alternative
Get them a kitten.
Yes! Kittens r a very good idea
Well I would probably try to provide them with resources to help them quit. I would also tell them they could come to me for help at any time if they needed it.

A friend of mine quit two weeks ago. Every time he gets the urge to smoke, I remind him how bad is health would be if he picked it up again and how much progress he's already made. A little motivation goes a long way!
Yes it does
Well seeing as how I still smoke if I had a friend trying to quit I wouldn't smoke around them or even bring it up. Just gives me another excuse for not smoking anyways
I would tell them to talk to me every time they want a cigarette. I know if I had someone who was just willing to listen to me vent, I'd be less inclined to pick up a cigarette.
Have them check out this study and see if they would like to continue smoking afterwards. Motivation from other members in the group could help as well
#1: Share a success that you’ve had in the past. It can be anything from any time. Why did it work? Who helped? #motivation

The summer after I graduated High School I backpacked Europe for a month by myself. It was such a feeling of accomplishment to realize I, at the time 18 years old, traveled over 10,000 miles and to 6 different countries. My grandmother funded this backpacking trip for me and I was able to talk to friends and family back home easily. I feel it worked out because of my determination and love of travel.

I think my greatest success so far was the day I graduated from basic training in the military. I was fit, tan, and motivated to start my job training. The looks on my parents faces were priceless, I don't think I will ever forget how proud they were that day. All in all just a great feeling and a great day!

The day I birthed my daughter hearing her first cries after nine hot agonizing months was the most amazing thing I've ever heard. Being a young mother is hard 21, juggling a full time job and running your normal life but all the more rewarding at the end of the day.
I just got a perfect score on my biology exam because I studied before hand. What helped was getting fustrated with non perfect scores in the past and being hard on myself knowing I could do better.

I think my biggest success was simply finally accepting things as they come and realizing that I can't change things. For so long I freaked and obsessed over things out of my control and now I've learned to calm down and not let things get to me as much.

I would have to say that personally my biggest success was realizing my biggest problem in life was myself. In which I mean that all that was going wrong was merely due to my own actions and mindset. My father was a big roll in this but my older brother who I love dearly was the main source as I made the realization that his struggles were his own doings, it dawned on me that I was on the same path as him. It's not that we live terrible lives or anything like that. We just created most, if not all, of our troubles on our own. Once I made the mindset that I can have major influence on my entire existence and nothing else does, to plan for the future but still live for the day, it was hard to not succeed.

My most recent success is leaving the fast food/restaurant industry and getting a rewarding job in a doctors office. I took a chance going for something I never thought I'd get and surprised myself with my interview abilities and adaption skills.
All amazing success, everyone! (y)
Hi everyone and welcome to TSP! I am available for the next hour. Let me know if you have any questions! #TDII

Welcome to the Tobacco Status Project! Who's ready to get this show on the road?! We will start posting TOMORROW (7/22) at 12 noon PDT! We will share one post everyday for 90 days. Remember to turn on your notifications and check this page daily! Dr. Johannes Thrul will be joining us for 1 hour each week, during which he will answer any tobacco-related questions, share info and resources, and provide support to our group. Stay tuned for his first session!

data.message: This group is for 18-25 year olds who currently smoke and are thinking of quitting. Learn more information about all the treatment options you can use, how to prepare and combat cravings and withdrawal, how to build up your support system AND get tips for successfully staying quit. Make your game plan here, then execute with confidence in the future. Please engage with our posts and comment every day!
